ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Study of anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching in Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunction assembly

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching in Ag/NiO/ITO (Indium–Tin–Oxide) heterojunctional thin film assembly is investigated. A sequential voltage sweep in 0 → V max → 0 → −V min → 0 order shows intrinsic hysteresis behaviour and resistive switching in current density (J)–voltage (V) measurements at room temperature. Switching is induced by possible rupture and recovery of the conducting filaments in NiO layer mediated by oxygen ion migration and interfacial effects at NiO/ITO junction. In the high-resistance OFF-state space charge limited current passes through the filamentary path created by oxygen ion vacancies. In OFF-state, the resistive switching behaviour is attributed to trapping and detrapping processes in shallow trap states mostly consisting of oxygen vacancies. The slope of Log I vs Log V plots, in shallow trap region of space charge limited conduction is ~2 (I ∝ V 2) followed by trap-filled and trap-free conduction. In the low-resistance ON-state, the observed electrical features are governed by the ohmic conduction.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: In metal/metal-oxide/metal heterojunctional switching devices, the resistance of a insulator/dielectric thin film swings between a high-resistance OFF-state and a low-resistance ON-state under appropriate current or voltage pulses across the electrodes [1–5]. Reports suggest that the resistive switching is related to the charge storage and it relies on the nanoelectromechanical behaviour of the active materials [6–10]. The effective charge trapping and trap depths in the active element such as TiO2, NiO, Cu2O or metal/polymer nanocomposite thin films affect the threshold voltage shift [6, 7, 11–13]. Between two kinds of resistive switching behaviours, viz. unipolar and bipolar switching, the latter involves amplitude as well as the polarity of the input voltage/current, making it directional in nature [2]. Unipolar switching registers high ON/OFF ratios, but requires large reset current. However, bipolar switching requires lower operational power and it records faster switching speed compared to the unipolar switching [14] and [15]. Proper choice of switching mode can broaden the scope of application of these resistive switching-based memory devices. Kim et al. [16] point out that the bipolar resistance switching in Pt/TiO2/Pt assembly involves the intermediate phase with oxygen vacancy between the insulating TiO2 and the residual conducting filament that formed at the interface region. Vasu et al. [17] observe that a critical concentration of oxygen vacancy and the formation of transition metal anion nanofilaments are necessary for switching. Lee and Hwang [18] employ scanning probe microscopy (SPM) to understand the nanoscale filamentary conducting paths between the two electrodes in the close vicinity of the electrode/film interface. It is also reported that the type and nature of electrodes affect the device functionality [19, 20]. For example, the non-polar and bipolar resistive state in TiO2 thin film can be switched by choosing either Pt or Al as the top electrode [21, 22]. Thus, several theoretical models such as the Schottky barrier model [23], the filamentary model [24], space charges limited current (SCLC) [25] and the oxygen migration through redox process [26] have been proposed to understand the mechanism of resistive switching.

In this report, the switching behaviour of Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunctional assembly is discussed. The observed current–voltage features are analysed to interpret a possible mechanism for obtained anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching.

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para: For the active oxide layer, 0.002 mol of Ni(NO3)2, 6H2O is dissolved in distilled water and NaOH (0.025 mol) is added under stirring. The greenish precipitate is collected, washed in distilled water and alcohol successively to remove unreacted salt and excess NaOH. Residual greenish precipitate is dissolved in 2-ethoxyethanol and acetic acid (1.1 N) is added under vigorous stirring to obtain clear Ni-based solution. The obtained solution is aged and spin coated on quartz as well as ITO coated glass substrates at 3,500 rpm for 20 s. The spin coatings are repeated for two times (sample A) and six times (sample B), respectively. The intermediate step between successive coatings involves drying the films at 75 °C for 20 min. Finally, NiO films coated on quartz substrates are annealed at 450, 600, 700 and 1,000 °C for 1.5 h in air and NiO films coated on ITO/glass substrates are annealed at 450 °C for 1.5 h in air.

The crystallographic phase of the deposited NiO films is studied with X-ray diffractometer (XRD) [Bruker AXS (D8 advance)] supported by LynXEye super-speed detector and Ni-filtered Cu-Kα (λ = 0.15406 nm) radiation generated at 45 kV/40 mA. The alignment is done to find the optimized settings for z-axis, ω, ϕ etc. by performing manual scanning for appropriate sample position. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Hitachi 4800) in cross-sectional mode is used for thickness measurements. Topographic feature is studied with an atomic force microscope (multimode AFM, Nanoscope IV).

For electrical studies, top Ag electrode (2 × 2 mm2, 50 nm thickness) is deposited by RF sputtering technique in pure Ar (20 sccm) at a constant working pressure of 1.5 × 10−3 Torr and RF power of 60 W. I–V characteristics are studied with semiconducting parameter analyzer (Keithley 4200-SCS).

Section2.Heading: Crystallography and morphology
Section2.Para:
Figure 1a shows distinct crystalline peaks for sample A on quartz substrates, annealed at 700 °C and above, while at lower annealing temperature (450 °C), the films mostly remain amorphous. XRD peaks correspond to (101), (012) and (104) parallel lattice planes of cubic NiO are identified, confirming phase purity of the active element [27]. A representative topographic image of the NiO thin film (sample A) is shown in Fig. 1b. The surface roughness of the film is measured in terms of root-mean-square (rms) value as ~0.69 nm. In Fig. 1c, d, the cross-sectional FESEM images show the thickness of sample A (~20 nm) and that of sample B (~80 nm) deposited on ITO, respectively.
Fig. 1
a Grazing incidence XRD pattern of polycrystalline NiO thin films showing evolution of phase with temperature. b AFM image of spin coated two layered NiO film grown on quartz substrate and annealed at 450 °C for 1.5 h in air (sample A). c, d cross-sectional FESEM images show that the thicknesses of two layered (sample A) and 6 layered (sample B) NiO films annealed at 450 °C for 1.5 h in air are about 25 and 80 nm, respectively

Section2.Heading: Current (I)–voltage (V) in Ag/NiO/ITO assembly
Section2.Para:
Schematic in lower inset of Fig. 2a shows the arrangements to study current density (J)–voltage (V) characteristics of the Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunctional assembly. Bias voltage is applied at the bottom electrode (ITO) while top electrode (Ag) is grounded. The measurements reveal asymmetric J–V loops with non-linear rectifying features following the voltage sweep 0 → V max → 0 → −V min → 0 in sequence, shown by the arrows in Fig. 2a (sample A) and Fig. 2b (sample B). In what is known as “SET” process, during the positive sweep, the assembly is switched from a higher resistance state (HRS) to a lower resistance state (LRS). A reverse situation takes place in the “RESET” process, where LRS changes to HRS. This observed positive SET and negative RESET operations are termed anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching. Upper insets of Fig. 2a, b showing resistive switching curves in log scale for first two sweeps. Comparison of J–V characteristics for sample A and sample B revealed that switching is occurring in sample B at a lower voltage (1.1 V with positive bias and −0.8 V with negative bias) compared to sample A (1.75 V with positive bias and −1.8 V with negative bias). J–V hysteresis loop is found to be more symmetric about the origin in case of sample A with respect to sample B.
Fig. 2
J–V characteristics of sample A (a) and sample B (b), respectively, showing anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching. Upper inset in a and b showing RS curves in log scale for first two sweeps. Lower inset in a is schematic representation of Ag/NiO/ITO assembly with top electrode grounded and bias applied at bottom electrode

In the course of present study, it is observed that in the Ag/NiO/ITO assembly, the bipolar resistive switching is observed only when bias is applied at the bottom ITO electrode and top Ag electrode is grounded. An intrinsic resistance memory effect is directly evident from the reproducible J–V hysteresis for both samples A and B. The asymmetric nature of the hysteretic curves, as seen in Fig. 2, is attributed to the different work functions of the electrodes in the assembly under consideration. The relatively high current response under external bias is an indicative of the low-resistance state [28–30]. For sample A, R (ON)forward = 2.4 kΩ and R (OFF)forward = 5.8 kΩ and that for sample B, R (ON)forward = 2 kΩ and R (OFF)forward = 4.8 kΩ at 1 V (E = V/L ~ 0.15 MV/cm, L is the total thickness of NiO film and the Ag electrode), respectively. Thus both samples record identical R ON/R OFF ratio (Fig. 2). Contrary to this scenario, when bias is applied on top Ag electrode and bottom ITO electrode is grounded, the assembly records only diode like J–V features, but failed to register any switching response and is shown in Fig. 3. Non-linear non-rectifying J–V characteristics probably originating from the two back to back junction diodes, viz. Schottky type (Ag/NiO) and the p-n junction type (NiO/ITO), with one junction as forward biased and another as reverse biased in the present case. Hence reversing the ground terminal and the terminal where the bias is applied to the Ag/NiO/ITO assembly, dissimilar current conduction mechanisms are evoked [31, 32]. The observed J–V features depend on resistivity, doping concentration, carrier mobility and also the geometry and the properties of the contacts, band alignment at the interfaces and change in work functions of the materials. All these parameters have direct effect on the current conduction [33, 34]. With the bias applied at Ag electrode and ITO electrode kept grounded, semi-direct XPS technique performed on NiO thin film and ITO substrate reveals that at NiO/ITO interface the valance and conduction band off set values are ∆E V = 2.6 eV and ∆E C = 2.4 eV, respectively, for sample A [33, 35]. In this process, the value of the band gap used is determined from the UV–VIS measurements performed on the samples (figure not shown). The band offset values at the NiO/ITO junction are quite high with respect to barrier height at Ag/NiO contact, which is around 0.99 eV [36]. Hence, under biased condition at the Ag/NiO and NiO/ITO junctions’ current flow is not identical. This fact has direct effect on the reduced current density value as well as on the dissimilar current density values at positive and negative bias voltages in case of Fig. 3. This issue still needs some more investigations.
Fig. 3
In sample A, diode like J–V features, but with no switching response is noticed when bias is applied on top Ag electrode and ITO bottom electrode is grounded. Inset is schematic representation of Ag/NiO/ITO assembly with top electrode grounded and bias applied at bottom electrode

Ag/NiO/ITO assembly consists of two immediate interfacial regions, viz. the Ag/NiO (NiO is Ni- deficient p-type semiconductor), and the NiO/ITO contact zones [28, 29]. Between this, Ag/NiO interface can either form an ohmic or a Schottky contact [30–37]. It is known that the Schottky barrier formation at the Ag/NiO interface is favourable with work function of Ag ~4.26 eV, as well as the band gap of NiO ~3.93 eV [38–40]. In some cases, the oxide layer formation at the metal/semiconductor interface also contributes to the resistive switching [25, 41]. As the free energy of oxidation for Ag is much higher than Ni, the possibility of silver oxide layer formation at the Ag/NiO interface is less in this present case. [37] Studies reveal that switching behaviour is observed in Pt/NiO/Pt or Au/NiO/Pt assemblies with Ohmic contacts and Ag/NiO/Pt, Al/NiO/Pt and Ti/NiO/Pt with Schottky contacts [30]. Moreover, the bipolar switching in the present heterojunctional assembly is different from the reported unipolar switching observed in Ag/NiO/Pt assembly, where Ag/NiO forms Schottky contact [38, 42]. Phark et al. [42] in their work ascribe the inconsistent switching behaviour of Ag/NiO/Pt assemblies on the differences in interfacial chemical interaction that affects the filament formation and rupture processes near the electrode. It is thus important to mention that the switching property of a metal-oxide-metal structure is determined by the type of electrodes used as well as its chemical reactivity with the active thin film materials. For example, Pt/NiO/Pt–Ir structures show unipolar switching where Pt and Pt–Ir being inert and as they form ohmic contacts with NiO, the transport properties of the Pt/NiO/Pt–Ir assembly were solely determined by the NiO film [43]. On the other hand, in Pt/NiO/SrRuO3 assembly, the bottom electrode SrRuO3 being quite different from an inert metal, plays significant role in bipolar switching [25, 44]. It is thus concluded that in the present Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunctional assembly, Ag/NiO interfacial properties contribute to the asymmetry and rectifying features (Fig. 2) and ITO film is presumed to contribute to the bipolar resistive switching [23]. Higher potential barrier between Ni-deficient NiO and heavily doped ITO affects the flow of current through the assembly [45].

Schematic in Fig. 4 summarizes the mechanism for switching observed in Ag/NiO/ITO assembly. It is reported [2] that the oxygen ions (O2−) and oxygen vacancies (
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$

) move through the grain boundaries and interstitial sites, and participate in overall conduction of the assembly. Heavily doped n-type ITO contains surplus of oxygen vacancies. During annealing of the film samples, (O2−) ions migrate from p-type NiO to the
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
sites in ITO and a less conducting oxide layer is formed at the NiO/ITO interface (Fig. 4a) [25]. When low positive bias (E < 0.14 MV/cm) is applied at the bottom electrode and the top electrode is grounded, negatively charged (O2−) ions are accumulated near the NiO/ITO interface (Fig. 4b). This generates a substantial voltage drop at that NiO/ITO interface and small amount of current flows owing to the thermally generated charge carriers. As a result, HR state is achieved. If the positive bias is high (E > 0.14 MV/cm), accumulated (O2−) ions at the NiO/ITO interface can penetrate into the barrier. Oxygen vacancies in ITO side serve as the trap sites for the (O2−) ions. [46, 47]. O2− ions get trapped and detrapped within ITO layer under the bias [48]. Trapping of carriers (doping effect) in ITO side reduces the potential barrier at the NiO/ITO interface region. This reduction helps in further conduction of the charge carriers. At the same time, (O2−) ions drift towards ITO leaving behind
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
within the film. Thus
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
vacancies line up, starting from the bottom of the NiO film up to the top electrode to form a conduction path for electrons (Fig. 4c). At Ag/NiO interface, accumulated
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
act as two-electron trapping site and lead to the reduction of the Schottky-like barrier height at the Ag/NiO junction. Thus, electrons from Ag pass through the thin Schottky-like barrier via tunnelling. Disappearance of the rectification behaviours occurs at Ag/NiO junction and ohmic contact is established consequently, LRS is achieved (Fig. 4c) [2, 49]. LRS is sustained even if small negative bias is applied at ITO. At this stage (O2−) ions remain trapped until the applied negative bias is large enough to push the (O2−) ions away from ITO. When negative bias applied on ITO with Ag electrode grounded, (O2−) ions trapped in ITO moved back towards NiO. This cause a rupture of the conduction path near the vicinity of NiO/ITO interface and oxygen vacancies
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
are again get distributed in ITO increasing the potential barrier at the junction and HRS is established (Fig. 4d). Hence conduction mechanism is trap-assisted tunnelling type [50–53].
Fig. 4
Schematic diagram of conduction mechanism within Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunctional assembly during SET and RESET processes with positive and negative biases applied, respectively, at the bottom electrode while the top electrode is grounded

Further analysis of I–V characteristics is shown in Fig. 5. The Log I vs Log V plots show linear features with variable slopes of 1.1–1.4 at low applied bias ≤1.2 V (or E ≤ 0.17 MV/cm) for sample A and up to ~1.0 V (or E ≤ 0.14 MV/cm) for sample B. This linear behaviour (I ∝ V) is controlled by the thermally generated carriers and corresponds to Fig. 4a, b with no bias applied or very small positive bias applied to ITO and with Ag grounded. However, as the number of the injected carriers exceeds the number of thermally generated carriers, conduction is controlled by the trapping of carriers at the shallow traps and current conduction thus follows Eq. 1,
Fig. 5
Log I–Log V curves for samples A (a) and B (b), respectively when positive bias is applied to the bottom electrode and top electrode is grounded, and the solid lines are segmented linear fitting with different slopes depicting different current mechanisms. Insets of the figures are showing the Log I–Log V curves for the HRS and LRS conductions when negative bias is applied to the bottom electrode and the top electrode is grounded
1
$$ I = \frac{9}{8}\varepsilon \mu \theta \frac{{V^{2} }}{{L^{3} }} $$
I =
9 8
ε μ θ
V 2
L 3
where, ε is the dielectric constant, θ is the density ratio of free to shallow trapped carriers, L is the film thickness, and μ is the carrier mobility. As mentioned earlier, the resistive switching behaviour is attributed to trapping and detrapping processes in shallow trap states mostly consisting of
$$ V_{0}^{ \bullet } $$
V
0
∙
[30, 54] as discussed in Fig. 4. The slope in shallow trap region (between V = 1.2 and 1.5) is ~2.5 (I ∝ V2.5, for sample A; Fig. 5a). Conversely, as revealed in Fig. 5b, the shallow trap region is not prominent for sample B [55]. This part mimics the schematic Fig. 4b which shows, the drift of (O2−) ions from NiO to the vacancy sites at ITO by the application of positive bias on ITO and their trapping at the vacancy sites in ITO. With further increase in voltage, more carriers are injected from NiO to ITO, and eventually, fill up most of the trapping sites in ITO. Once saturated, the excess charges in the defect level appear in the conduction band and produce sudden rise in current. In this trap-filled-limited (TFL) regime [43], the steep rise in current gives a steeper slope in the Log I–Log V curve. For sample A, the slope is ~7.1, for V ≥ 1.5 V (E ≥ 0.21 MV/cm) and for sample B the slope is ~4.3, for 0.9 ≤ V ≤ 1.2 V (0.07 ≤ E ≤ 0.09 MV/cm) [56]. This part represents the ‘SET’ process as shown and discussed in Fig. 4b, c. Moreover, in sample B, the trap-filled region is followed by a trap-free conduction regime owing to self-blockage of the charge carriers which follows trap-free Child’s square law [2] given by Eq. 2, 2
$$ I = \frac{9}{8}\varepsilon \mu \frac{{V^{2} }}{{L^{3} }} $$

V 2
L 3

The slope of the Log I–Log V curve for sample B in trap-free region is ~2.2 within the region 1.2 ≤ V ≤ 2 V (0.0.09 ≤ E ≤ 0.15 MV/cm). It is significant to note at this point that in sample A, LRS is governed by initial trap-free conduction region (Child’s square law) with a slope of 2.9 and then is followed by ohmic conduction. In sample B ohmic conduction dominates and linear dependence is observed throughout the whole studied voltage range of LRS. This region represents the LRS mechanism as is predicted in Fig. 4c with ohmic conduction at Ag/NiO interface, conducting channel formation within NiO and reduced barrier at NiO/ITO p–n junction. These mechanisms altogether allow a smooth flow of current through the circuit. In the samples under study above mentioned three regions in Log I–Log V curves viz. Ohmic conduction, shallow trap conduction and finally trap-free conduction are signature of space charge limited current conduction mechanism. Thus, space charge limited current conduction mechanism dominates mostly the HRS for both of the samples A and B.

The insets of Fig. 5a, b show the HRS and LRS conductions for negative bias applied to the bottom electrode and the top electrode is grounded. It is evident from the discussion that the hysteresis I–V feature is the result of dissimilar conduction mechanism involved in HRS and LRS in both sample A and B.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: In summary, we have reported anti-clockwise bipolar resistive switching effect in Ag/NiO/ITO heterojunctional assembly. The intrinsic hysteresis current–voltage behaviour is analysed. The SET/RESET response of NiO thin films is studied as a function of active layer thickness though not much difference in the two cases was observed. For sample A, initial trap-free conduction region with a slope of ~2.9 is followed by ohmic conduction in LRS. In sample B, the ohmic conduction dominates the entire voltage range in LRS. HRS behaviour in both of the samples is dominated by space charge limited current conduction mechanism. Switching is induced by possible rupture and recovery of the conducting filaments in NiO layer mediated by oxygen ion migration and interfacial effects.
